what: List of Exported Functions (Used in New Vignette)
title: Linear and Nonlinear Mixed Effects Models
text: Descriptions provided R Documentation lme: Linear Mixed-Effects Models: generic function fits linear mixed-effects model formulation described Laird Wre (1982) allowing nested random effects. within-group errors allowed correlated /unequal variances anova.lme: Compare Likelihoods Fitted Objects: Likelihood ratio test two lme model objects

title: Linear and Nonlinear Mixed Effects Models
text: basic example shows solve common problem (lme R Documentation):
code: fm1 <- lme(distance ~ age, Orthodont, random = ~ age | Subject) anova(fm1) fm2 <- update(fm1, random = pdDiag(~age)) anova(fm1, fm2)

what: Autocorrelation Function for gls Residuals — ACF.gls
title: Autocorrelation Function for gls Residuals — ACF.gls
text: method function calculates empirical autocorrelation function   residuals gls fit. grouping variable   specified form, autocorrelation values   calculated using pairs residuals within group;   otherwise possible residual pairs used. autocorrelation   function useful investigating serial correlation models   equally spaced data.

title: Autocorrelation Function for gls Residuals — ACF.gls
code: # S3 method for gls ACF(object, maxLag, resType, form, na.action, ...)

title: Autocorrelation Function for gls Residuals — ACF.gls
text: object object inheriting class "gls", representing     generalized least squares fitted  model. maxLag optional integer giving maximum lag     autocorrelation calculated. Defaults maximum lag     residuals. resType optional character string specifying type     residuals used. "response", "raw" residuals     (observed - fitted) used; else, "pearson",     standardized residuals (raw residuals divided corresponding     standard errors) used; else, "normalized",     normalized residuals (standardized residuals pre-multiplied     inverse square-root factor estimated error correlation     matrix) used. Partial matching arguments used,     first character needs provided. Defaults "pearson". form optional one sided formula form ~ t,     ~ t | g, specifying time covariate t ,  optionally,     grouping factor g. time covariate must integer     valued. grouping factor present      form, autocorrelations calculated using residual pairs     within group. Defaults ~ 1, corresponds     using order observations data covariate,     groups. na.action function indicates happen     data contain NAs.  default action (na.fail) causes     ACF.gls print error message terminate     incomplete observations. ... methods generic require additional     arguments.

title: Autocorrelation Function for gls Residuals — ACF.gls
text: data frame columns lag ACF representing,   respectively, lag residuals within pair corresponding   empirical autocorrelation. returned value inherits class  ACF.

what: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.gls
title: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.gls
text: one fitted model object present, data frame   numerator degrees freedom, F-values, P-values   Wald tests terms model (Terms   L NULL), combination model terms (  Terms NULL), linear combinations model   coefficients (L NULL). Otherwise,   multiple fitted objects compared, data frame   degrees freedom, (restricted) log-likelihood,    Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), Bayesian Information   Criterion (BIC) object returned. test=TRUE,   whenever two consecutive  objects different number degrees   freedom, likelihood ratio statistic associated p-value   included returned data frame.

title: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.gls
code: # S3 method for gls anova(object, ..., test, type, adjustSigma, Terms, L, verbose)

title: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.gls
text: object object inheriting class "gls",    representing generalized least squares fit. ... optional fitted model objects inheriting    classes "gls", "gnls", "lm", "lme",    "lmList", "nlme", "nlsList", "nls". test optional logical value controlling whether likelihood    ratio tests used compare fitted models represented    object objects .... Defaults    TRUE. type optional character string specifying type sum    squares used F-tests terms model.     "sequential", sequential sum squares obtained    including terms order appear model used;    else, "marginal", marginal sum squares    obtained deleting term model time used.    argument used single fitted object passed    function. Partial matching arguments used, first    character needs provided. Defaults "sequential". adjustSigma optional logical value. TRUE    estimation method used obtain object maximum    likelihood, residual standard error multiplied    \(\sqrt{n_{obs}/(n_{obs} - n_{par})}\),    converting REML-like estimate. argument used    single fitted object passed function. Default    TRUE. Terms optional integer character vector specifying    terms model jointly tested zero using Wald    F-test. given character vector, elements must correspond    term names; else, given integer vector, elements must    correspond order terms included    model. argument used single fitted object    passed function. Default NULL. L optional numeric vector array specifying linear    combinations coefficients model tested    zero. given array, rows define linear    combinations tested. names assigned vector    elements (array columns), must correspond coefficients    names used map linear combination(s)    coefficients; else, names available, vector elements    (array columns) assumed order coefficients    appear model. argument used single fitted    object passed function. Default NULL. verbose optional logical value. TRUE, calling    sequences fitted model object printed rest    output, omitted verbose = FALSE. Defaults    FALSE.

text: Likelihood comparisons meaningful objects fit using   restricted maximum likelihood different fixed effects.

title: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.gls
code: # AR(1) errors within each Mare fm1 <- gls(follicles ~ sin(2*pi*Time) + cos(2*pi*Time), Ovary,            correlation = corAR1(form = ~ 1 | Mare)) anova(fm1) #> Denom. DF: 305  #>                    numDF  F-value p-value #> (Intercept)            1 354.7332  <.0001 #> sin(2 * pi * Time)     1  18.5034  <.0001 #> cos(2 * pi * Time)     1   1.6633  0.1981 # variance changes with a power of the absolute fitted values? fm2 <- update(fm1, weights = varPower()) anova(fm1, fm2) #>     Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm1     1  5 1571.455 1590.056 -780.7273                         #> fm2     2  6 1570.925 1593.247 -779.4626 1 vs 2 2.529261  0.1118  # Pinheiro and Bates, p. 251-252 fm1Orth.gls <- gls(distance ~ Sex * I(age - 11), Orthodont,                 correlation = corSymm(form = ~ 1 | Subject),                 weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1 | age)) fm2Orth.gls <- update(fm1Orth.gls,                 corr = corCompSymm(form = ~ 1 | Subject)) anova(fm1Orth.gls, fm2Orth.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm1Orth.gls     1 14 452.5468 489.5683 -212.2734                         #> fm2Orth.gls     2  9 449.9724 473.7719 -215.9862 1 vs 2 7.425576  0.1909  # Pinheiro and Bates, pp. 215-215, 255-260 #p. 215 fm1Dial.lme <-   lme(rate ~(pressure + I(pressure^2) + I(pressure^3) + I(pressure^4))*QB,       Dialyzer, ~ pressure + I(pressure^2)) # p. 216 fm2Dial.lme <- update(fm1Dial.lme,                   weights = varPower(form = ~ pressure)) # p. 255 fm1Dial.gls <- gls(rate ~ (pressure +      I(pressure^2) + I(pressure^3) + I(pressure^4))*QB,         Dialyzer) fm2Dial.gls <- update(fm1Dial.gls,                  weights = varPower(form = ~ pressure)) anova(fm1Dial.gls, fm2Dial.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm1Dial.gls     1 11 761.1707 792.7136 -369.5853                         #> fm2Dial.gls     2 12 738.2206 772.6310 -357.1103 1 vs 2 24.95006  <.0001 fm3Dial.gls <- update(fm2Dial.gls,                     corr = corAR1(0.771, form = ~ 1 | Subject)) anova(fm2Dial.gls, fm3Dial.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm2Dial.gls     1 12 738.2206 772.6310 -357.1103                         #> fm3Dial.gls     2 13 642.6746 679.9526 -308.3373 1 vs 2 97.54602  <.0001 # anova.gls to compare a gls and an lme fit  anova(fm3Dial.gls, fm2Dial.lme, test = FALSE) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik #> fm3Dial.gls     1 13 642.6746 679.9526 -308.3373 #> fm2Dial.lme     2 18 648.0798 699.6955 -306.0399  # Pinheiro and Bates, pp. 261-266 fm1Wheat2 <- gls(yield ~ variety - 1, Wheat2) fm3Wheat2 <- update(fm1Wheat2,       corr = corRatio(c(12.5, 0.2),         form = ~ latitude + longitude, nugget = TRUE)) # Test a specific contrast  anova(fm3Wheat2, L = c(-1, 0, 1)) #> Denom. DF: 168  #>  F-test for linear combination(s) #> varietyARAPAHOE varietyBUCKSKIN  #>              -1               1  #>   numDF  F-value p-value #> 1     1 7.696728  0.0062

title: Compare Likelihoods of Fitted Objects — anova.lme
code: fm1 <- lme(distance ~ age, Orthodont, random = ~ age | Subject) anova(fm1) #>             numDF denDF   F-value p-value #> (Intercept)     1    80 3096.4871  <.0001 #> age             1    80   85.8464  <.0001 fm2 <- update(fm1, random = pdDiag(~age)) anova(fm1, fm2) #>     Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test   L.Ratio p-value #> fm1     1  6 454.6367 470.6173 -221.3183                          #> fm2     2  5 453.3146 466.6318 -221.6573 1 vs 2 0.6778943  0.4103  ## Pinheiro and Bates, pp. 251-254 ------------------------------------------ fm1Orth.gls <- gls(distance ~ Sex * I(age - 11), Orthodont,        correlation = corSymm(form = ~ 1 | Subject),        weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1 | age)) fm2Orth.gls <- update(fm1Orth.gls,           corr = corCompSymm(form = ~ 1 | Subject)) ## anova.gls examples: anova(fm1Orth.gls, fm2Orth.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm1Orth.gls     1 14 452.5468 489.5683 -212.2734                         #> fm2Orth.gls     2  9 449.9724 473.7719 -215.9862 1 vs 2 7.425576  0.1909 fm3Orth.gls <- update(fm2Orth.gls, weights = NULL) anova(fm2Orth.gls, fm3Orth.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm2Orth.gls     1  9 449.9724 473.7719 -215.9862                         #> fm3Orth.gls     2  6 445.7572 461.6236 -216.8786 1 vs 2 1.784873  0.6182 fm4Orth.gls <- update(fm3Orth.gls, weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1 | Sex)) anova(fm3Orth.gls, fm4Orth.gls) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm3Orth.gls     1  6 445.7572 461.6236 -216.8786                         #> fm4Orth.gls     2  7 436.1887 454.6994 -211.0943 1 vs 2 11.56859   7e-04 # not in book but needed for the following command fm3Orth.lme <- lme(distance ~ Sex*I(age-11), data = Orthodont,                    random = ~ I(age-11) | Subject,                    weights = varIdent(form = ~ 1 | Sex)) # Compare an "lme" object with a "gls" object (test would be non-sensical!) anova(fm3Orth.lme, fm4Orth.gls, test = FALSE) #>             Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik #> fm3Orth.lme     1  9 429.5225 453.3220 -205.7612 #> fm4Orth.gls     2  7 436.1887 454.6994 -211.0943  ## Pinheiro and Bates, pp. 222-225 ------------------------------------------ op <- options(contrasts = c("contr.treatment", "contr.poly")) fm1BW.lme <- lme(weight ~ Time * Diet, BodyWeight, random = ~ Time) fm2BW.lme <- update(fm1BW.lme, weights = varPower()) # Test a specific contrast anova(fm2BW.lme, L = c("Time:Diet2" = 1, "Time:Diet3" = -1)) #> F-test for linear combination(s) #> Time:Diet2 Time:Diet3  #>          1         -1  #>   numDF denDF  F-value p-value #> 1     1   157 2.862569  0.0926  ## Pinheiro and Bates, pp. 352-365 ------------------------------------------ fm1Theo.lis <- nlsList(      conc ~ SSfol(Dose, Time, lKe, lKa, lCl), data=Theoph) fm1Theo.lis #> Call: #>   Model: conc ~ SSfol(Dose, Time, lKe, lKa, lCl) | Subject  #>    Data: Theoph  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          lKe        lKa       lCl #> 6  -2.307332  0.1516234 -2.973242 #> 7  -2.280370 -0.3860511 -2.964335 #> 8  -2.386437  0.3188339 -3.069111 #> 11 -2.321530  1.3478239 -2.860397 #> 3  -2.508073  0.8975422 -3.229965 #> 2  -2.286108  0.6640568 -3.106317 #> 4  -2.436494  0.1582638 -3.286087 #> 9  -2.446088  2.1821879 -3.420774 #> 12 -2.248326 -0.1828442 -3.170158 #> 10 -2.604148 -0.3631216 -3.428271 #> 1  -2.919614  0.5751612 -3.915857 #> 5  -2.425486  0.3862853 -3.132600 #>  #> Degrees of freedom: 132 total; 96 residual #> Residual standard error: 0.7001921 fm1Theo.nlme <- nlme(fm1Theo.lis) #> Warning: Iteration 2, LME step: nlminb() did not converge (code = 1). Do increase 'msMaxIter'! fm2Theo.nlme <- update(fm1Theo.nlme, random= pdDiag(lKe+lKa+lCl~1) ) fm3Theo.nlme <- update(fm2Theo.nlme, random= pdDiag(    lKa+lCl~1) )  # Comparing the 3 nlme models anova(fm1Theo.nlme, fm3Theo.nlme, fm2Theo.nlme) #>              Model df      AIC      BIC    logLik   Test  L.Ratio p-value #> fm1Theo.nlme     1 10 366.6417 395.4697 -173.3208                         #> fm3Theo.nlme     2  6 366.0429 383.3397 -177.0214 1 vs 2 7.401190  0.1161 #> fm2Theo.nlme     3  7 368.0470 388.2266 -177.0235 2 vs 3 0.004123  0.9488  options(op) # (set back to previous state)

title: Augmented Predictions — augPred
text: object fitted model object predictions can    extracted, using predict method. primary optional one-sided formula specifying primary    covariate used generate augmented predictions.    default,  covariate can extracted data used generate    object (using getCovariate), used    primary. minimum optional lower limit primary    covariate. Defaults min(primary). maximum optional upper limit primary    covariate. Defaults max(primary). length.optional integer number primary    covariate values evaluate predictions.  Defaults    51. level optional integer vector specifying desired    prediction levels.  Levels increase outermost innermost    grouping, level 0 representing population (fixed effects)    predictions.  Defaults innermost level. ... methods generic may require additional    arguments.

title: Create a groupedData object from a matrix — balancedGrouped
code: balancedGrouped(form, data, labels=NULL, units=NULL)

title: Create a groupedData object from a matrix — balancedGrouped
text: form formula form y ~ x | g giving name    response, primary covariate, grouping factor. data matrix data frame containing values    response grouped according levels grouping factor    (rows) distinct levels primary covariate (columns).    dimnames matrix used construct levels    grouping factor primary covariate. labels optional list character strings giving labels    response primary covariate.  label primary    covariate named x response named    y.  Either label can omitted. units optional list character strings giving units    response primary covariate.  units string    primary covariate named x response    named y.  Either units string can omitted.

Letting   \(d\) denote range \(n\) denote nugget   effect, correlation two observations distance   \(r\) apart \(\exp(-r/d)\) nugget effect   present \((1-n) \exp(-r/d)\) nugget   effect assumed. code: corExp(value, form, nugget, metric, fixed)

title: Exponential Correlation Structure — corExp
text: value optional vector parameter values    constrained form. nugget FALSE, value can    one element, corresponding "range"    exponential correlation structure, must greater    zero. nugget TRUE, meaning nugget effect    present, value can contain one two elements, first    "range" second "nugget effect" (one minus    correlation two observations taken arbitrarily close    together); first must greater zero second must    zero one. Defaults numeric(0), results    range 90% minimum distance nugget effect 0.1    assigned parameters object initialized. form one sided formula form ~ S1+...+Sp,    ~ S1+...+Sp | g, specifying spatial covariates S1    Sp ,  optionally, grouping factor g.     grouping factor present form, correlation    structure assumed apply observations within    grouping level; observations different grouping levels    assumed uncorrelated. Defaults ~ 1, corresponds    using order observations data covariate,    groups. nugget optional logical value indicating whether nugget    effect present. Defaults FALSE. metric optional character string specifying distance    metric used. currently available options    "euclidean" root sum--squares distances;    "maximum" maximum difference; "manhattan"    sum absolute differences. Partial matching    arguments used, first three characters need    provided. Defaults "euclidean". fixed optional logical value indicating whether    coefficients allowed vary optimization, kept    fixed initial value. Defaults FALSE, case    coefficients allowed vary.

title: Refinery yield of gasoline — Gasoline

"REML" model fit    maximizing restricted log-likelihood.  "ML"    log-likelihood maximized. Default    FALSE. apVar logical value indicating whether approximate    covariance matrix variance-covariance parameters    calculated.  Default TRUE. .relStep relative step numerical derivatives    calculations. Default .Machine$double.eps^(1/3). opt optimizer used, either "nlminb" (   current default) "optim" (previous default). optimMethod character - optimization method used    optim optimizer. default    "BFGS".  alternative "L-BFGS-B". minAbsParApVar numeric value - minimum absolute parameter value    approximate variance calculation.  default 0.05. natural logical.  natural parameterization used    approximate variance calculations?  Default TRUE. sigma optionally positive number fix residual error .    NULL, default, 0, sigma estimated.

title: LME fit from lmList Object — lme.lmList
text: computational methods follow general framework Lindstrom   Bates (1988). model formulation described Laird Ware   (1982).  variance-covariance parametrizations described   Pinheiro Bates (1996).  different correlation structures   available correlation argument described Box,   Jenkins Reinse (1994), Littel et al (1996), Venables   Ripley, (2002). use variance functions linear nonlinear   mixed effects models presented detail Davidian Giltinan   (1995). Box, G.E.P., Jenkins, G.M., Reinsel G.C. (1994) "Time Series   Analysis: Forecasting Control", 3rd Edition, Holden--Day. Davidian, M. Giltinan, D.M. (1995) "Nonlinear Mixed Effects Models   Repeated Measurement Data", Chapman Hall. Laird, N.M. Ware, J.H. (1982) "Random-Effects Models   Longitudinal Data", Biometrics, 38, 963--974. Lindstrom, M.J. Bates, D.M. (1988) "Newton-Raphson EM   Algorithms Linear Mixed-Effects Models Repeated-Measures   Data", Journal American Statistical Association, 83,   1014--1022. Littel, R.C., Milliken, G.., Stroup, W.W., Wolfinger, R.D. (1996)   "SAS Systems Mixed Models", SAS Institute. Pinheiro, J.C. Bates., D.M.  (1996) "Unconstrained   Parametrizations Variance-Covariance Matrices", Statistics   Computing, 6, 289--296. Venables, W.N. Ripley, B.D. (2002) "Modern Applied Statistics   S", 4th Edition, Springer-Verlag.

title: Specifying Control Values for lme Fit — lmeControl
code: lmeControl(maxIter = 50, msMaxIter = 50, tolerance = 1e-6, niterEM = 25,            msMaxEval = 200,      msTol = 1e-7, msVerbose = FALSE,            returnObject = FALSE, gradHess = TRUE, apVar = TRUE,      .relStep = .Machine$double.eps^(1/3), minAbsParApVar = 0.05,            opt = c("nlminb", "optim"),      optimMethod = "BFGS", natural = TRUE,      sigma = NULL,            allow.n.lt.q = FALSE,            ...)

title: Specifying Control Values for lme Fit — lmeControl
text: maxIter maximum number iterations lme    optimization algorithm.  Default 50. msMaxIter maximum number iterations    optimization step inside lme optimization.    Default 50. tolerance tolerance convergence criterion    lme algorithm. Default 1e-6. niterEM number iterations EM algorithm used refine    initial estimates random effects variance-covariance    coefficients.  Default 25. msMaxEval maximum number evaluations objective    function permitted nlminb.  Default 200. msTol tolerance convergence criterion first    iteration optim used.  Default 1e-7. msVerbose logical value passed trace argument    nlminb optim.  Default FALSE. returnObject logical value indicating whether fitted    object returned warning (instead    error via stop()) maximum number    iterations reached without convergence algorithm.  Default    FALSE. gradHess logical value indicating whether numerical gradient    vectors Hessian matrices log-likelihood function    used internal optimization.  option available    correlation structure (corStruct) variance    function structure (varFunc) "varying" parameters    pdMat classes used random effects structure    pdSymm (general positive-definite), pdDiag (diagonal),    pdIdent (multiple identity),     pdCompSymm (compound symmetry).  Default TRUE. apVar logical value indicating whether approximate    covariance matrix variance-covariance parameters    calculated.  Default TRUE. .relStep relative step numerical derivatives    calculations.  Default .Machine$double.eps^(1/3). opt optimizer used, either "nlminb" (   default) "optim". optimMethod character - optimization method used    optim optimizer.  default    "BFGS".  alternative "L-BFGS-B". minAbsParApVar numeric value - minimum absolute parameter value    approximate variance calculation.  default 0.05. natural logical value indicating whether pdNatural    parametrization used general positive-definite matrices    (pdSymm) reStruct, approximate covariance    matrix estimators calculated.  Default TRUE. sigma optionally positive number fix residual error .    NULL, default, 0, sigma estimated. allow.n.lt.q logical indicating ok    less observations random effects group.  default,    FALSE signals error; NA, situation gives    warning, nlme versions prior 2019; true, message    given .  ... named control arguments passed, depending    opt, nlminb (abs.tol )    optim (except trace maxit;    reltol used second iteration).

title: Specifying Control Values for lme Fit — lmeControl
code: # decrease the maximum number iterations in the ms call and # request that information on the evolution of the ms iterations be printed str(lCtr <- lmeControl(msMaxIter = 20, msVerbose = TRUE)) #> List of 17 #>  $ maxIter       : num 50 #>  $ msMaxIter     : num 20 #>  $ tolerance     : num 1e-06 #>  $ niterEM       : num 25 #>  $ msMaxEval     : num 200 #>  $ msTol         : num 1e-07 #>  $ msVerbose     : logi TRUE #>  $ returnObject  : logi FALSE #>  $ gradHess      : logi TRUE #>  $ apVar         : logi TRUE #>  $ .relStep      : num 6.06e-06 #>  $ opt           : chr "nlminb" #>  $ optimMethod   : chr "BFGS" #>  $ minAbsParApVar: num 0.05 #>  $ natural       : logi TRUE #>  $ sigma         : num 0 #>  $ allow.n.lt.q  : logi FALSE ## This should always work: do.call(lmeControl, lCtr) #> $maxIter #> [1] 50 #>  #> $msMaxIter #> [1] 20 #>  #> $tolerance #> [1] 1e-06 #>  #> $niterEM #> [1] 25 #>  #> $msMaxEval #> [1] 200 #>  #> $msTol #> [1] 1e-07 #>  #> $msVerbose #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $returnObject #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradHess #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $apVar #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $.relStep #> [1] 6.055454e-06 #>  #> $opt #> [1] "nlminb" #>  #> $optimMethod #> [1] "BFGS" #>  #> $minAbsParApVar #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $natural #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $sigma #> [1] 0 #>  #> $allow.n.lt.q #> [1] FALSE #>

title: Fitted lme Object — lmeObject
text: object returned lme function, inheriting class   "lme" representing fitted linear mixed-effects   model.  Objects class methods generic functions   anova, coef, fitted, fixed.effects,   formula, getGroups, getResponse,   intervals, logLik, pairs, plot,   predict, print, random.effects, residuals,   sigma, summary, update, vcov.

title: Fitted lme Object — lmeObject
text: following components must included legitimate "lme" object. apVar approximate covariance matrix     variance-covariance coefficients.  apVar = FALSE     control values used call lme, component     NULL. call list containing image lme call     produced object. coefficients list two components, fixed     random, first vector containing estimated     fixed effects second list matrices estimated     random effects level grouping. matrix     random list, columns refer random effects     rows groups. contrasts list contrast matrices used represent factors     fixed effects formula  /random effects formula.     information important making predictions new data     frame levels original factors     observed. factors used lme model, component     empty list. dims list basic dimensions used lme fit,     including components N - number observations     data, Q - number grouping levels, qvec -     number random effects level innermost     outermost (last two values equal zero correspond     fixed effects response), ngrps - number groups     level innermost outermost (last two values one     correspond fixed effects response),     ncol - number columns model matrix     level grouping innermost outermost (last two values     equal number fixed effects one). fitted data frame fitted values columns.     leftmost column corresponds population fixed effects     (corresponding fixed effects ) successive columns     left right correspond increasing levels grouping. fixDF list components X terms     specifying denominator degrees freedom , respectively,     t-tests individual fixed effects F-tests     fixed-effects terms models. groups data frame grouping factors     columns. grouping level increases left right. logLik (restricted) log-likelihood convergence. method estimation method: either "ML" maximum     likelihood, "REML" restricted maximum likelihood. modelStruct object inheriting class lmeStruct,     representing list mixed-effects model components,     reStruct, corStruct, varFunc objects. numIter number iterations used iterative     algorithm. residuals data frame residuals columns.     leftmost column corresponds population residuals     successive columns left right correspond increasing     levels grouping. sigma estimated within-group error standard deviation. varFix approximate covariance matrix     fixed effects estimates.

title: Fitted lme Object — lmeObject
text: José Pinheiro Douglas Bates bates@stat.wisc.edu

title: Tenderness of meat — Meat

Six storage periods ranging 0 18 days used.   Thirty roasts scored four judges scale 0 10,   score increasing tenderness. response sum   four scores. Left right roasts animal grouped   pairs, grouped five blocks, according   muscle extracted. Different storage periods   applied roast within pair according balanced   incomplete block design.

text: following components must included legitimate "nlme" object. apVar approximate covariance matrix     variance-covariance coefficients. apVar = FALSE     control values used call nlme, component     NULL. call list containing image nlme call     produced object. coefficients list two components, fixed     random, first vector containing estimated     fixed effects second list matrices estimated     random effects level grouping. matrix     random list, columns refer random effects     rows groups. contrasts list contrast matrices used represent factors     fixed effects formula  /random effects formula.     information important making predictions new data     frame levels original factors     observed. factors used nlme model, component     empty list. dims list basic dimensions used nlme fit,     including components N - number observations     data, Q - number grouping levels, qvec -     number random effects level innermost     outermost (last two values equal zero correspond     fixed effects response), ngrps - number groups     level innermost outermost (last two values one     correspond fixed effects response),     ncol - number columns model matrix     level grouping innermost outermost (last two values     equal number fixed effects one). fitted data frame fitted values columns.     leftmost column corresponds population fixed effects     (corresponding fixed effects ) successive columns     left right correspond increasing levels grouping. fixDF list components X terms     specifying denominator degrees freedom , respectively,     t-tests individual fixed effects F-tests     fixed-effects terms models. groups data frame grouping factors     columns. grouping level increases left right. logLik (restricted) log-likelihood convergence. map list components fmap, rmap,     rmapRel, bmap, specifying various mappings     fixed random effects, used generate predictions     fitted object. method estimation method: either "ML" maximum     likelihood, "REML" restricted maximum likelihood. modelStruct object inheriting class nlmeStruct,     representing list mixed-effects model components,     reStruct, corStruct, varFunc objects. numIter number iterations used iterative     algorithm. residuals data frame residuals columns.     leftmost column corresponds population residuals     successive columns left right correspond increasing     levels grouping. sigma estimated within-group error standard deviation. varFix approximate covariance matrix     fixed effects estimates.

what: General Positive-Definite Matrix in Natural Parametrization — pdNatural
title: General Positive-Definite Matrix in Natural Parametrization — pdNatural
text: function constructor pdNatural class,   representing general positive-definite matrix, using natural   parametrization . matrix associated object   dimension \(n\), represented \(n(n+1)/2\)   parameters. Letting \(\sigma_{ij}\) denote \(ij\)-th   element underlying positive definite matrix   \(\rho_{ij}=\sigma_{}/\sqrt{\sigma_{ii}\sigma_{jj}},\;\neq j\) denote associated   "correlations", "natural" parameters given   \(\sqrt{\sigma_{ii}}, \;=1,\ldots,n\)   \(\log((1+\rho_{ij})/(1-\rho_{ij})),\; \neq     j\). Note   natural parameters individually unrestricted, jointly   unrestricted (meaning unrestricted vectors give   positive-definite matrices). Therefore, parametrization   used optimization. mostly used deriving   approximate confidence intervals parameters following   optimization objective function. value   numeric(0), uninitialized pdMat object, one-sided   formula, vector character strings, object returned   uninitialized pdSymm object (just   attributes class defined) needs coefficients   assigned later, generally using coef matrix replacement   functions. value initialized pdMat object,   object constructed   .matrix(value). Finally, value numeric    vector, assumed represent natural parameters   underlying positive-definite matrix.

text: data frame contains following columns: Subject factor identifying patient data collected. time numeric vector giving time (hr) drug       administered blood sample drawn.  measured       time patient entered study. conc numeric vector giving serum quinidine concentration (mg/L). dose numeric vector giving dose drug administered (mg).       Although two different forms quinidine       administered, doses adjusted differences       salt content conversion milligrams quinidine base. interval numeric vector giving drug given       regular intervals sufficiently long period time       assume steady state behavior, interval recorded. Age numeric vector giving age subject entry       study (yr). Height numeric vector giving height subject entry       study (.). Weight numeric vector giving body weight subject (kg). Race factor levels       Caucasian,        Latin,       Black identifying race subject. Smoke factor levels             yes giving smoking status time       measurement. Ethanol factor levels       none,        current,       former giving ethanol (alcohol) abuse status       time measurement. Heart factor levels       /Mild,        Moderate,        Severe indicating congestive heart failure subject. Creatinine ordered factor levels       < 50 < >= 50 indicating creatinine clearance (mg/min). glyco numeric vector giving alpha-1 acid glycoprotein       concentration (mg/dL).  Often measured time       quinidine concentration.

title: Quinidine Kinetics — Quinidine
text: Verme et al. (1992) analyze routine clinical data   patients receiving drug quinidine treatment cardiac   arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation ventricular arrhythmias).    patients receiving oral quinidine doses.  irregular intervals   blood samples drawn serum concentrations quinidine   determined.  data   analyzed several publications, including Davidian Giltinan (1995,   section 9.3).

text: Intravenous infusion remifentanil (strong analgesic) different   rates varying time periods applied total 65 patients.   Concentration measurements remifentanil taken along several   covariates resulting Remifentanil data frame 2107 rows   12 columns.

title: Pharmacokinetics of Remifentanil — Remifentanil
code: data("Remifentanil", package = "nlme")

title: Pharmacokinetics of Remifentanil — Remifentanil
text: data frame (class "groupedData", specifically   "nfnGroupedData") contains following columns: ID: numerical (patient) IDs. Subject: ordered factor 65 levels (      IDs): 30 < 21 < 25 < 23 <       29 < ... ... < 36 < 6 < 5 < 10 < 9. Time: time beginning infusion minutes (numeric). conc: remifentanil concentration [ng / ml] (numeric). Rate: infusion rate [µg / min]. Amt: amount remifentanil given current time interval [µg]. Age: age patient years. Sex: gender patient, factor levels       Female Male. Ht: height patient cm. Wt: weight patient kg. BSA: body surface area (DuBois DuBois 1916): \(% 	BSA := Wt^{0.425} \cdot Ht^{0.725} \cdot 0.007184\). LBM: lean body mass (James 1976), slightly different       formula         men \(LBM_m := 1.1  Wt - 128 (Wt/Ht)^2\),       women \(LBM_f := 1.07 Wt - 148 (Wt/Ht)^2\).

Max.  #>   20.00   22.00   24.00   32.42   42.00   54.00  ## between 20 and 54 measurements per patient (median: 24; mean: 32.42)  ## Only first measurement of each patient : dim(Remi.1 <- Remifentanil[!duplicated(Remifentanil[,"ID"]),]) #  65 x 12 #> [1] 65 12  LBMfn <- function(Wt, Ht, Sex) ifelse(Sex == "Female",                                         1.07 * Wt - 148*(Wt/Ht)^2,                                         1.1  * Wt - 128*(Wt/Ht)^2) with(Remi.1,     stopifnot(all.equal(BSA, Wt^{0.425} * Ht^{0.725} * 0.007184, tol = 1.5e-5),               all.equal(LBM, LBMfn(Wt, Ht, Sex),                 tol = 7e-7) ))  ## Rate: typically  3 µg / kg body weight, but : sunflowerplot(Rate ~ Wt, Remifentanil) abline(0,3, lty=2, col=adjustcolor("black", 0.5))

title: Extract lme Residuals — residuals.lme
text: object object inheriting class "lme", representing    fitted linear mixed-effects model. level optional integer vector giving level(s) grouping     used extracting residuals object. Level     values increase outermost innermost grouping,     level zero corresponding population residuals. Defaults     highest innermost level grouping. type optional character string specifying type     residuals used.  "response", default,     “raw” residuals (observed - fitted) used; else,     "pearson",     standardized residuals (raw residuals divided corresponding     standard errors) used; else, "normalized",     normalized residuals (standardized residuals pre-multiplied     inverse square-root factor estimated error correlation     matrix) used. Partial matching arguments used,     first character needs provided. asList optional logical value. TRUE single     value given level, returned object list     residuals split groups; else returned value     either vector data frame, according length     level. title: Random Effects Structure — reStruct
text: function constructor reStruct class,   representing random effects structure consisting list   pdMat objects, plus settings attribute containing   information optimization algorithm used fit associated   mixed-effects model.

title: Random Effects Structure — reStruct
code: reStruct(object, pdClass, REML, data) # S3 method for reStruct print(x, sigma, reEstimates, verbose, ...)

title: Random Effects Structure — reStruct
text: object following: () one-sided formula form    ~x1+...+xn | g1/.../gm, x1+...+xn specifying    model random effects g1/.../gm grouping    structure (m may equal 1, case /    required). random effects formula repeated levels    grouping, case multiple levels grouping; (ii) list    one-sided formulas form ~x1+...+xn | g, possibly    different random effects models grouping level. order    nesting assumed order elements    list; (iii) one-sided formula form ~x1+...+xn,    pdMat object formula (.e. non-NULL value    formula(object)), list formulas pdMat    objects. case, grouping structure formula derived    data used fit mixed-effects model,    inherit class groupedData; (iv) named list formulas    pdMat objects (iii), grouping factors    names. order nesting assumed order    order elements list; (v) reStruct object. pdClass optional character string name    pdMat class used formulas    object. Defaults "pdLogChol" corresponds    general positive-definite matrix (Log-Cholesky parametrization). REML optional logical value. TRUE, associated    mixed-effects model fitted using restricted maximum    likelihood; else, FALSE, maximum likelihood    used. Defaults FALSE. data optional data frame evaluate variables    used random effects formulas object. used    obtain levels factors, affect dimensions    row/column names underlying pdMat objects.    NULL, attempt made obtain information    factors appearing formulas. Defaults    parent frame function called. x object inheriting class reStruct printed. sigma optional numeric value used multiplier    square-root factors pdMat components (usually    estimated within-group standard deviation mixed-effects    model). Defaults 1. reEstimates optional list random effects estimates    level grouping. used verbose = TRUE. verbose optional logical value determining random    effects estimates printed. Defaults FALSE. ... Optional arguments can given methods    generic.  None used method.

title: Constant Plus Power Variance Function — varConstPower
text: function constructor varConstPower class,   representing constant plus power variance function   structure. Letting \(v\) denote variance covariate   \(\sigma^2(v)\) denote variance function evaluated   \(v\), constant plus power variance function defined   \(\sigma^2(v) = (\theta_1 + |v|^\theta_2)^2\), \(\theta_1,\theta_2\) variance     function coefficients. grouping factor present, different   \(\theta_1,\theta_2\) used factor level.

title: Constant Plus Power Variance Function — varConstPower
text: const, power optional numeric vectors, lists numeric     values, , respectively, coefficients constant      power terms. arguments must length one, unless     grouping factor specified form. either argument     length greater one, must names identify     elements levels grouping factor defined     form. grouping factor present      form argument length one, value     assigned grouping levels. positive values allowed     const. Default numeric(0),     results vector zeros appropriate length assigned     coefficients object initialized (corresponding     constant variance equal one). form optional one-sided formula form ~ v,     ~ v | g, specifying variance covariate v ,     optionally, grouping factor g coefficients.     variance covariate must evaluate numeric vector may involve     expressions using ".", representing  fitted model object     fitted values (fitted(.)) residuals     (resid(.)) can extracted (allows variance     covariate updated optimization object     function). grouping factor present form,     different coefficient value used     levels. Several grouping variables may     simultaneously specified, separated * operator,     ~ v | g1 * g2 * g3. case, levels     grouping variable pasted together resulting factor     used group observations. Defaults ~ fitted(.)     representing variance covariate given fitted values     fitted model object grouping factor. fixed optional list components const /    power, consisting numeric vectors, lists numeric     values, specifying values     coefficients variance function fixed. grouping     factor specified form, components fixed     must names identifying coefficients     fixed. Coefficients included fixed allowed vary     optimization objective function. Defaults     NULL, corresponding fixed coefficients.

what: Constant Plus Proportion Variance Function — varConstProp
title: Constant Plus Proportion Variance Function — varConstProp
text: function constructor varConstProp class,   representing variance function structure corresponding   two-component error model (additive proportional error). Letting   \(v\) denote variance covariate \(\sigma^2(v)\)   denote variance function evaluated \(v\), two-component variance   function defined   \(\sigma^2(v) = ^2 + b^2 * v^{2}\),   additive component b relative error component.  order   avoid overparameterisation model, recommended use   possibility fix sigma, preferably value 1 (see examples).

Default 0.1 const     prop. form optional one-sided formula form ~ v,     ~ v | g, specifying variance covariate v ,     optionally, grouping factor g coefficients.     variance covariate must evaluate numeric vector may involve     expressions using ".", representing  fitted model object     fitted values (fitted(.)) residuals     (resid(.)) can extracted (allows variance     covariate updated optimization object     function). grouping factor present form,     different coefficient value used     levels. Several grouping variables may     simultaneously specified, separated * operator,     ~ v | g1 * g2 * g3. case, levels     grouping variable pasted together resulting factor     used group observations. Defaults ~ fitted(.)     representing variance covariate given fitted values     fitted model object grouping factor. fixed optional list components const /    power, consisting numeric vectors, lists numeric     values, specifying values     coefficients variance function fixed. grouping     factor specified form, components fixed     must names identifying coefficients     fixed. Coefficients included fixed allowed vary     optimization objective function. Defaults     NULL, corresponding fixed coefficients.

text: José Pinheiro Douglas Bates (varConstPower)   Johannes Ranke (adaptation varConstProp()).

title: Constant Plus Proportion Variance Function — varConstProp
code: # Generate some synthetic data using the two-component error model and use # different variance functions, also with fixed sigma in order to avoid # overparameterisation in the case of a constant term in the variance function times <- c(0, 1, 3, 7, 14, 28, 56, 120) pred <- 100 * exp(- 0.03 * times) sd_pred <- sqrt(3^2 + 0.07^2 * pred^2) n_replicates <- 2  set.seed(123456) syn_data <- data.frame(   time = rep(times, each = n_replicates),   value = rnorm(length(times) * n_replicates,     rep(pred, each = n_replicates),     rep(sd_pred, each = n_replicates))) syn_data$value <- ifelse(syn_data$value < 0, NA, syn_data$value)  f_const <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3)) f_varPower <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3),   weights = varPower()) f_varConstPower <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3),   weights = varConstPower()) f_varConstPower_sf <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   control = list(sigma = 1),   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3),   weights = varConstPower()) f_varConstProp <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3),   weights = varConstProp()) f_varConstProp_sf <- gnls(value ~ SSasymp(time, 0, parent_0, lrc),   data = syn_data, na.action = na.omit,   start = list(parent_0 = 100, lrc = -3),   control = list(sigma = 1),   weights = varConstProp())  AIC(f_const, f_varPower, f_varConstPower, f_varConstPower_sf,   f_varConstProp, f_varConstProp_sf) #>                    df      AIC #> f_const             3 108.4453 #> f_varPower          4 106.6988 #> f_varConstPower     5 108.6988 #> f_varConstPower_sf  4 110.4453 #> f_varConstProp      5 108.9603 #> f_varConstProp_sf   4 106.9603  # The error model parameters 3 and 0.07 are approximately recovered intervals(f_varConstProp_sf) #> Approximate 95% confidence intervals #>  #>  Coefficients: #>              lower       est.      upper #> parent_0 98.609809 105.173540 111.737272 #> lrc      -3.599219  -3.483158  -3.367097 #>  #>  Variance function: #>            lower        est.     upper #> const  0.9913302  2.45553887  6.082404 #> prop  -0.1186579 -0.07702744 -0.035397 #>  #>  Residual standard error: #> [1] 1 1 1

title: Calculate Semi-variogram for Residuals from a gls Object — Variogram.gls
text: object object inheriting class "gls", representing     generalized least squares fitted model. distance optional numeric vector distances     residual pairs. grouping variable present,     distances residual pairs within group     given. missing, distances calculated based     values arguments form, data,     metric, unless object includes corSpatial     element, case associated covariate (obtained     getCovariate method) used. form optional one-sided formula specifying covariate(s)     used calculating distances residual pairs ,     optionally, grouping factor partitioning residuals (    must appear right | operator     form). Default ~1, implying observation      order within groups used obtain distances. resType optional character string specifying type     residuals used. "response", "raw" residuals     (observed - fitted) used; else, "pearson",     standardized residuals (raw residuals divided corresponding     standard errors) used; else, "normalized",     normalized residuals (standardized residuals pre-multiplied     inverse square-root factor estimated error correlation     matrix) used. Partial matching arguments used,     first character needs provided. Defaults "pearson". data optional data frame interpret variables     form. default, data used fit object     used. na.action function indicates happen     data contain NAs. default action (na.fail) causes     error message printed function terminate,     incomplete observations. maxDist optional numeric value maximum distance used     calculating semi-variogram two residuals. default     residual pairs included. length.optional integer value. object     includes corSpatial element, semi-variogram values     calculated argument used length.    argument corresponding Variogram method. Defaults     50. collapse optional character string specifying type     collapsing applied individual semi-variogram values.     equal "quantiles", semi-variogram values split     according quantiles distance distribution, equal     number observations per group, possibly varying distance     interval lengths. Else, "fixed", semi-variogram values     divided according distance intervals equal lengths,     possibly different number observations per interval. Else,     "none", collapsing used individual     semi-variogram values returned. Defaults "quantiles". nint optional integer number intervals     used collapsing semi-variogram values. Defaults 20. robust optional logical value specifying robust     semi-variogram estimator used collapsing     individual values. TRUE robust estimator     used. Defaults FALSE. breaks optional numeric vector breakpoints     distance intervals used collapsing semi-variogram     values. missing, option specified collapse     ignored. metric optional character string specifying distance     metric used. currently available options     "euclidean" root sum--squares distances;     "maximum" maximum difference; "manhattan"     sum absolute differences. Partial matching     arguments used, first three characters need     provided. Defaults "euclidean". ... methods generic require additional     arguments.  None used method.
